analyzed: pūrṇasya pūrṇam ādāya pūrṇam eva avaśiṣyate

analyzed: kham brahma

analyzed: kham purāṇam

analyzed: veda enena yat veditavyam
translated: By this Veda, what is to be known is...

original: pūrṇamadaḥ pūrṇaṃ na kutaścid vyāvṛttaṃ vyāpītyetat /
analyzed: pūrṇam adaḥ pūrṇam na kutaścid vyāvṛttam vyāpi iti etat
translated: The full is this, the full is that, the full is not excluded from anywhere, it is all-pervading - this is the meaning.

analyzed: niṣṭhā ca kartari draṣṭavyā
translated: And the ending should be seen in the agent.

analyzed: adaḥ iti parokṣa abhidhāyi sarvanāma
translated: The pronoun that expresses the indirect object.

analyzed: tat param brahma iti arthaḥ
translated: Its meaning is the supreme Brahman.

original: tat sampūrṇamākāśavad vyāpi nirantaraṃ nirupādhikaṃ ca tadevedaṃ sopādhikaṃ nāmarūpasthaṃvyavahārāpannaṃ pūrṇaṃ svena rūpeṇa paramātmanā vyāpyeva
analyzed: tat sampūrṇam ākāśa vat vyāpi nirantaram nirupādhikam ca tat eva idam sopādhikam nāma rūpa sthaṃvyavahāra āpannam pūrṇam svena rūpeṇa paramātmanā vyāpya iva
translated: That is full, all-pervading like space, uninterrupted, and without limitations. That alone is this, which has become limited by adjuncts, abiding in names and forms, subject to conventions, full, pervaded by its own nature, the supreme Self,

analyzed: na upādhi paricchinnena viśeṣa ātmanā
translated: not by a particular nature limited by adjuncts.

original: tadidaṃ viśeṣāpannaṃ kāryātmakaṃ brahma pūrṇāt kāraṇātmana udacyata udricyata udgacchatītyetat /🔽yadyapi kāryātmanodricyate tathāpi yat svarūpaṃ pūrṇatvaṃ paramātmabhāvaṃ tanna jāhāti pūrṇamevodricyate /
analyzed: tat idam viśeṣa āpannam kārya ātmakam brahma pūrṇāt kāraṇa ātmanaḥ udacyate udricyate udgacchati iti etat  yadi api kārya ātmanā udricyate tathā api yat svarūpam pūrṇa tvam paramātma bhāvam tat na jāhāti pūrṇam eva udricyate
translated: This Brahman, which is now qualified by its effects, rises up, i.e., comes forth, from the complete Brahman, which is the cause.🔽Even though it rises up as the Brahman of effects, still it does not abandon its own nature, its completeness, its state of the supreme Self. It rises up as complete only.

original: pūrṇasya kāryātmano brahmaṇaḥ pūrṇa pūrṇatvamādāya gṛhītvā ātmasvarūpaikarasatvamāpadya /
analyzed: pūrṇasya kāryātmanaḥ brahmaṇaḥ pūrṇa pūrṇa tvam ādāya gṛhītvā ātma svarūpa ekarasa tvam āpadya
translated: Having taken up the completeness of the complete Brahman, which is the effect, having grasped it, it becomes of the same essence as its own nature.

original: vidyayā avidyākṛtaṃ bhūtamātropādhisaṃsargajamanyatvāvabhāsaṃ tiraskṛtya pūrṇamevānantaramavāhyaṃ prajñānaghanaikarasasvabhāvaṃ kevalaṃ brahmāvaśiṣyate
analyzed: vidyayā avidyā kṛtam bhūtamātra upādhi saṃsarga jam anya tva avabhāsam tiraskṛtya pūrṇam eva anantaram avāhyam prajñāna ghana eka rasa svabhāvam kevalam brahma avaśiṣyate
translated: By knowledge, having set aside the state of being other, which arises from the contact with the limiting adjuncts of the mere elements created by ignorance, it remains only as the complete, infinite, external, pure Brahman, whose nature is of the essence of the mass of knowledge.

analyzed: yat uktam brahma vai idam agre āsīt tat ātmānam eva avet tasmāt tat sarvam abhavat iti eṣaḥ u sya mantrasya arthaḥ
translated: As it is said: Brahman, verily, existed here in the beginning, one only. He knew himself: 'I am Brahman.' From him came forth all this. This is the meaning of this mantra.

analyzed: tatra brahmā ityasya arthaḥ pūrṇamadaḥ iti
translated: There, the meaning of Brahman is the complete one.

original: idaṃ pūrṇamiti brahma vā idamagra āsīdityasyārthaḥ /🔽tathā ca śrutyantaramyadeveha tadamutrayadamutra tadanvihaiti /
analyzed: idam pūrṇam iti brahma vai idam agre āsīt iti asya arthaḥ 🔽tathā ca śruti antaram yat eva iha tat amutra yat amutra tat anu iha eti
translated: The meaning of Brahman, verily, existed here in the beginning is this complete one.🔽And another scripture says: What is here, that is there; what is there, that is here.

original: ato 'daḥśabdavācyaṃ pūrṇaṃ brahma tadevedaṃ pūrṇaṃ kāryasthaṃ nāmarūpopādhisaṃyuktamavidyayodriktam /
analyzed: atas daḥ śabda vācyam pūrṇam brahma tat eva idam pūrṇam kārya stham nāma rūpa upādhi saṃyuktam avidyayā udriktam
translated: Therefore, the full Brahman, denoted by the word 'that', is the same as this full universe, existing as the effect, united with name and form as limiting adjuncts, and superimposed by ignorance.

analyzed: tasmāt eva paramārtha svarūpāt anyat iva pratyavabhāsamānam
translated: It appears as if it were different from that very nature of the highest truth.

original: tadyadātmānameva paraṃ pūrṇaṃ brahma viditvāhamadaḥ pūrṇaṃ brahmāsmītyevaṃ pūrṇamādāya
analyzed: tat yat ātmānam eva param pūrṇam brahma viditvā aham adaḥ pūrṇam brahma asmi iti evam pūrṇam ādāya
translated: When one, knowing the Self to be the highest full Brahman, takes up the full [Self] by thinking 'I am the full Brahman',

analyzed: tiraskṛtya āpūrṇa sva rūpa tām avidyā kṛtām nāma rūpa upādhi saṃparka jām etayā brahma vidyayā
translated: and sets aside the state of being incomplete, which is due to ignorance and arises from contact with the limiting adjuncts of name and form, by this knowledge of Brahman,

analyzed: pūrṇam eva kevalam avaśiṣyate
translated: only the full [Self] alone remains.

analyzed: tathā ca uktam tasmāt tat sarvam abhavati iti
translated: And it is said thus: 'Therefore, all this became'.

original: yaḥ sarvopaniṣadartho brahma sa eṣo 'nena mantreṇānūdyata uttarasambandhārtham /
analyzed: yaḥ sarva upaniṣad arthaḥ brahma saḥ eṣaḥ nena mantreṇa anūdyate uttara sambandha artham
translated: The meaning of all the Upanishads, which is Brahman, is referred to by this mantra for the purpose of connecting it with what follows.

original: brahmavidyāsādhanatvena hi vakṣyamāṇāni sādhanānyoṅkāradamadānadayākhyāni vidhitsitāni khilaprakaraṇasambandhātsarvopāsanāṅgabhūtāni ca /
analyzed: brahmavidyā sādhana tvena hi vakṣyamāṇāni sādhanāni oṅkāra dama dāna dayā ākhyāni vidhitsitāni khila prakaraṇa sambandhāt sarva upāsana aṅga bhūtāni ca
translated: For the means of knowledge of Brahman, which are to be enjoined, such as the syllable Om, self-control, charity, and compassion, are intended to be the means of all meditation, as is indicated by the connection with the chapter on the miscellaneous [Upanishad].

analyzed: atra eke varṇayanti pūrṇāt kāraṇāt pūrṇam kāryam udricyate
translated: Here some describe it thus: The full effect is superimposed on the full cause.

original: udriktaṃ kāryaṃ vartamānakāle 'pi pūrṇameva paramārthavastubhūtaṃ dvaitarūpeṇa /
analyzed: udriktam kāryam vartamāna kāle pi pūrṇam eva paramārtha vastu bhūtam dvaita rūpeṇa
translated: The increased effect, even at the time of the present, is complete in reality, in the form of duality.

original: punaḥ pralayakāle pūrṇasya kāryasya pūrṇatāmādāyā'tmani dhitvā pūrṇamevāvaśiṣyate kāraṇarūpam /
analyzed: punar pralaya kāle pūrṇasya kāryasya pūrṇa tām ādāya ātmani dhitvā pūrṇam eva avaśiṣyate kāraṇa rūpam
translated: Again, at the time of dissolution, taking away the completeness of the complete effect and placing it within itself, only the complete cause remains.

analyzed: evam utpatti sthiti pralayeṣu triṣu api kāleṣu kārya kāraṇayoḥ pūrṇa tā eva
translated: Thus, in all the three times of creation, sustenance and dissolution, the effect and the cause are complete.

analyzed: sā ca ekā eva pūrṇa tā kārya kāraṇayoḥ bhedena vyapadiśyate
translated: And that one completeness is designated as different in the effect and the cause.

analyzed: evam ca dvaita advaita ātmakam ekam brahma
translated: Thus, Brahman is one, having the nature of both non-duality and duality.

analyzed: yathā kila samudraḥ jala taraṅga phena budbuda ādi ātmakaḥ eva
translated: Just as the ocean is indeed of the nature of water, waves, foam, bubbles, etc.

original: yathā ca jalaṃ satyaṃ tadudbhavāśca taraṅgaphelabudbudādayaḥ samudrātmabhūtā evā'virbhāvatirobhāvadharmiṇaḥ paramārthasatyā eva /
analyzed: yathā ca jalam satyam tad udbhavāḥ ca taraṅga phela budbuda ādayaḥ samudra ātma bhūtāḥ eva āvirbhāva tirobhāva dharmiṇaḥ paramārtha satyāḥ eva
translated: And just as water is true, and the waves, foam, bubbles, etc. produced from it are indeed of the nature of the ocean itself, having the properties of appearance and disappearance, they are ultimately true.

original: evaṃ sarvamidaṃ dvaitaṃ paramārthasatyameva jalataraṅgādisthānīyaṃ samudrajalasthānīyaṃ tu paraṃ brahma /
analyzed: evam sarvam idam dvaitam paramārtha satyam eva jala taraṅga ādi sthānīyam samudra jala sthānīyam tu param brahma
translated: Thus, all this duality is ultimately true, like waves, foam, etc. in water, but the supreme Brahman is like the water in the ocean.

original: evaṃ ca kila dvaitasya satyatve karmakāṇḍasya prāmāṇyaṃ yadā punardvaitaṃ dvaitamivāvidyākṛtaṃ
analyzed: evam ca kila dvaitasya satya tve karmakāṇḍasya prāmāṇyam yadā punar dvaitam dvaitam iva avidyā kṛtam
translated: And thus, indeed, when duality is real, the Karmakāṇḍa is authoritative. But when duality, which is like duality, is created by ignorance,

original: mṛgatṛṣṇikāvadanṛtamadvaitameva paramārthatastadā kila karmakāṇḍaṃ viṣayābhāvādapramāṇaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: mṛgatṛṣṇikā vat anṛtam advaitam eva paramārthataḥ tadā kila karmakāṇḍam viṣaya abhāvāt apramāṇam bhavati
translated: like a mirage, it is not real, and is non-dual in reality, then indeed the Karmakāṇḍa becomes unauthoritative due to the absence of an object.

analyzed: tathā ca virodhaḥ eva syāt
translated: And thus there would be contradiction itself.

analyzed: veda eka deśa bhūta upaniṣad pramāṇam paramārtha advaita vastu pratipādaka tvāt apramāṇam karmakāṇḍam asat dvaita viṣaya tvāt
translated: The Upaniṣads, which are a part of the Veda, are authoritative because they teach the highest truth of non-dual reality. The Karmakāṇḍa is unauthoritative because it teaches unreal duality.

original: tadvirodhaparijihīrṣayā śrutyaitaduktaṃ kāryakāraṇayoḥ satyatvaṃ samudravatpūrṇamada ityādineti /
analyzed: tad virodha parijihīrṣayā śrutyā etat uktam kārya kāraṇayoḥ satya tvam samudra vat pūrṇa madaḥ ityādinā iti
translated: With the desire to avoid contradiction with that, the Śruti has said this: The effect and the cause are real, like the ocean, full, not empty, etc.

analyzed: tat asat
translated: That is not so.

analyzed: viśiṣṭa viṣaya apavāda vikalpayoḥ asambhavāt
translated: Because the exceptions to specific objects and the alternatives are impossible.

analyzed: na hi iyam su vivakṣitā kalpanā
translated: This conception is not well-conceived.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: yathā kriyā viṣaye utsarga prāptasya eka deśe pavādaḥ kriyate
translated: Just as an exception is made to what is obtained as a general rule in the case of a part of the object of an action,

original: yathāhiṃsansarvabhūtānyanyatra tīrthebhya iti hiṃsā sarvabhūtaviṣayotsargeṇa nivāritā tīrthe viśiṣṭaviṣaye jyotiṣṭomādāvanujñāyate /
analyzed: yathā a hiṃsan sarva bhūtāni anyatra tīrthebhyaḥ iti hiṃsā sarva bhūta viṣaya utsargeṇa nivāritā tīrthe viśiṣṭa viṣaye jyotiṣṭoma ādau anujñāyate
translated: For instance, the text, 'Without injuring any creature, except in the case of sacrifices,' prohibits injury to all creatures, and permits it in the case of sacrifices, which are a special case.

original: na ca tathā vastuviṣaya ihādvaitaṃ brahmotsargeṇa pratipādya punastadekadeśe 'pavadituṃ śakyate /
analyzed: na ca tathā vastu viṣaye iha advaitam brahma utsargeṇa pratipādya punar tad eka deśe śakyate
translated: And it is not possible to prohibit in general the non-dual Brahman, which is the object of knowledge, and then to allow a part of it again.

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ dvaita tvāt eva eka deśa anupapatteḥ
translated: Because Brahman is non-dual, it cannot have parts.

analyzed: tathā vikalpa anupapatteḥ ca
translated: And because an option is not possible.

original: yathātirātre ṣoḍaśinaṃ gṛhṇāti nātirātre ṣoḍaśinaṃ gṛhṇātīti grahaṇāgrahaṇayoḥ puruṣādhīnatvādvikalpo bhavati /
analyzed: yathā atirātre ṣoḍaśinam gṛhṇāti na atirātre ṣoḍaśinam gṛhṇāti iti grahaṇa agrahaṇayoḥ puruṣa adhīna tvāt vikalpaḥ bhavati
translated: For instance, in the case of the Atirâtra sacrifice, there is an option between taking and not taking the Ṣoḍaśin cup, because taking and not taking depend on the person.

original: na tviha tathā vastuviṣaye dvaitaṃ vā syādadvaitaṃ veti vikalpaḥ sambhavatyapuruṣatantratvādātmavastunaḥ /
analyzed: na tu iha tathā vastu viṣaye dvaitam vā syāt advaitam vā iti vikalpaḥ sambhavati apuruṣa tantra tvāt ātma vastunaḥ
translated: But in the case of an object, it is not possible to have an option between duality and non-duality, because the nature of the self is not dependent on the person.

analyzed: virodhāt ca dvaita advaita tvayoḥ ekasya
translated: And because duality and non-duality are mutually contradictory.

analyzed: tasmāt na su vivakṣitā iyam kalpanā
translated: Therefore, this assumption is not well-conceived.

analyzed: śruti nyāya virodhāt ca
translated: And because it contradicts the scriptures and reasoning.

analyzed: saindhava ghana vat prajñāna eka rasa ghanam nirantaram pūrva apara bāhya abhyantara bheda vivarjitam
translated: It is uninterrupted, like a lump of salt, a solid mass of the essence of knowledge, free from distinctions of before and after, inside and outside.

analyzed: sa bāhya abhyantaram ajam na iti na iti asthūlam an aṇu ajam ajaram abhayam amṛtam iti evamādyāḥ śrutayaḥ
translated: All the Vedic texts such as 'not so, not so' (Br. 2.3.6), 'not born' (Br. 2.5.19), 'not gross' (Br. 2.5.19), 'not small' (Br. 2.5.19), 'not old' (Br. 2.5.19), 'not new' (Br. 2.5.19), 'not dead' (Br. 2.5.19), 'not immortal' (Br. 2.5.19), and so on,

original: niścitārthāḥ saṃśayaviparyāsāśaṅkārahitāḥ sarvāḥ samudre prakṣiptāḥ syurakiñcitkaratvāt /
analyzed: niścita arthāḥ saṃśaya viparyāsa āśaṅkā rahitāḥ sarvāḥ samudre prakṣiptāḥ syuḥ akiñcitkara tvāt
translated: which have definite meanings, are free from doubt and error, and are free from suspicion, should all be thrown into the ocean, because they are useless.

analyzed: tathā nyāya virodhaḥ pi sāvayavasya aneka ātmakasya kriyāvataḥ nitya tva anupapatteḥ
translated: Similarly, there is also contradiction with logic, because it is not possible for something that has parts, that consists of many things, and that is active, to be eternal.

analyzed: nitya tvam ca ātmanaḥ smṛti ādi darśanāt anumīyate
translated: And eternality of the self is inferred from the observation of memory and so on.

analyzed: tad virodhaḥ ca prāpnoti anitya tve
translated: And there would be contradiction with that if it were non-eternal.

analyzed: bhavat kalpanā ānarthakyam ca
translated: And your conception would be pointless.

analyzed: sphuṭam eva ca asmin pakṣe karmakāṇḍa ānarthakyam
translated: And in this view, the futility of the section on ritual is clear.

analyzed: akṛta abhyāgama kṛta vipraṇāśa prasaṅgāt
translated: Because there would be the undesirable consequence of the acquisition of what was not done and the loss of what was done.

original: nanu brahmaṇo dvaitādvaitātmakatve samudrādidṛṣṭāntā vidyante kathamucyate bhavataikasya dvaitādvaitatvaṃ viruddhamiti / na /
analyzed: nanu brahmaṇaḥ dvaita advaita ātmaka tve samudra ādi dṛṣṭāntāḥ vidyante katham ucyate bhavatā ekasya dvaita advaita tvam viruddham iti na
translated: But if Brahman has the nature of both non-duality and duality, there are similes such as the ocean. How can it be said that duality and non-duality are contradictory in one? No.

analyzed: anya viṣaya tvāt
translated: Because they refer to different things.

original: nityāniravayavavastuviṣayaṃ hi viruddhatvamavocāma dvaitādvaitatvasya na kāryaviṣaye sāvayave /
analyzed: nitya a niravayava vastu viṣayam hi viruddha tvam avocāma dvaita advaita tvasya na kārya viṣaye sa avayave
translated: We have said that duality and non-duality are contradictory in reference to an eternal and partless reality, not in reference to an effect that has parts.

analyzed: tasmāt śruti smati nyāya virodhāt anupapannā iyam kalpanā
translated: Therefore, this conception is untenable, because it contradicts the Śruti, Smṛti, and reasoning.

analyzed: asyāḥ kalpanāyāḥ varam upaniṣad parityāgaḥ eva
translated: It is better to abandon the Upaniṣads altogether than to accept this conception.

analyzed: adhyeya tvāt ca na sa astra arthā iyam kalpanā
translated: And this conception is not the meaning of the scriptures, because it is to be studied.

original: na hi jananamaraṇādyanarthaśatasahasrabhedasamākulaṃ samudravanādivatsāvayavamanekarasaṃ brahma dhyeyatvena vijñeyatvena vā śrutyopadiśyate
analyzed: na hi janana maraṇa ādi anartha śata sahasra bheda samākulam samudra vana ādi vat sa avayavam aneka rasam brahma dhyeya tvena vijñeya tvena vā śrutyā upadiśyate
translated: For Brahman, which is full of hundreds of thousands of miseries such as birth, death, etc., which is composite like the ocean, the forest, etc., and has many tastes, is not taught by the Śruti as an object of meditation or knowledge.

analyzed: prajñāna ghana tām ca upadiśati
translated: It teaches the state of being pure knowledge.

analyzed: ekadhā eva anudraṣṭavyam iti ca
translated: And it says, One should see it as one only.

original: anekadhādarśanāpavādāccamṛtyoḥ sa mṛtyumāpnoti ya iha nāneva paśyatiiti /
analyzed: anekadhā darśana apavādāt ca mṛtyoḥ sa mṛtyum āpnoti yaḥ iha nānā iva paśyati iti
translated: And because of the denial of seeing in many ways, He who sees diversity here attains death from death.

analyzed: yat ca śrutyā ninditam tat na kartavyam
translated: And what is condemned by the Śruti should not be done.

original: yacca na kriyate na sa śāsrārthaḥ /
analyzed: yat ca na kriyate na sa śāsra arthaḥ
translated: And what is not done is not the meaning of the scriptures.

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ neka rasa tvam aneka dhātvam ca dvaita rūpam nindita tvāt na draṣṭavyam
translated: The diversity of Brahman in terms of having many tastes and being composed of many parts, which is of the nature of duality, should not be seen because it is condemned.

analyzed: atas na śāsra arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, it is not the meaning of the scriptures.

analyzed: yat tu eka rasa tvam brahmaṇaḥ tat draṣṭavya tvāt praśastam praśasta tvāt ca śāstra arthaḥ bhavitum arhati
translated: But the oneness of Brahman, which is to be seen, is praised. And because it is praised, it deserves to be the meaning of the scriptures.

original: yattūktaṃ vedaikadeśasyāprāmāṇyaṃ karmaviṣaye dvaitābhāvādadvaite ca prāmāṇyamiti /
analyzed: yat tu uktam veda eka deśasya aprāmāṇyam karma viṣaye dvaita abhāvāt advaite ca prāmāṇyam iti
translated: As for what was said - that one part of the Veda is not authoritative in the matter of action, and that in non-duality it is authoritative -

analyzed: tat na
translated: that is not so.

analyzed: yathā prāpta upadeśa artha tvāt
translated: Because it serves the purpose of teaching what is already known.

original: na hi dvaitamadvaitaṃ vā vastu jātamātrameva puruṣaṃ jñāpayitvā paścātkarma vā brahmavidyāṃ vopadiśati śāsram /
analyzed: na hi dvaitam advaitam vā vastu jāta mātram eva puruṣam jñāpayitvā paścāt karma vā brahma vidyām vā upadiśati śāsram
translated: For the scriptures do not teach action or knowledge of Brahman after first making the person know non-duality or duality, which are already existent.

analyzed: na ca upadeśa arham dvaitam jāta mātra prāṇi buddhi gamya tvāt

original: samūha saṃkṣipā'tmanastejo yenāhaṃ śaknuyāṃ tvatsvarūpamañjasā draṣṭam /

translated: Samūha means collect, sam means together, ūha means to raise up, the brilliance of yourself, by which I may be able to see your form quickly.

analyzed: vidyotanaḥ iva rūpāṇām atas upasaṃhara tejaḥ
translated: Vidyotain means like the illuminating of forms, therefore withdraw the brilliance.

original: yatte tava rūpaṃ sarvakalyāṇānāmatiśayena kalyāṇaṃ kalyāṇatamaṃ tatte paśyāmi /
analyzed: yat te tava rūpam sarva kalyāṇānām atiśayena kalyāṇam kalyāṇatamam tat te paśyāmi
translated: Yat means that which is your form, which is the most excellent of all auspicious things, that most auspicious one, I see.

analyzed: paśyāmaḥ vayam vacana vyatyayena
translated: We see by the reversal of the statement.

original: yo 'sau bhūrbhuvaḥsvarvyāhṛtyavayavaḥ puruṣaḥ puruṣākṛtitvātpuruṣaḥ so 'hamasmi bhavāmi /
analyzed: yaḥ sau bhūḥ bhuvaḥ svar vyāhṛti avayavaḥ puruṣaḥ puruṣa ākṛti tvāt puruṣaḥ saḥ ham asmi bhavāmi
translated: That Purusha, who is the component part of the Vyahrtis Bhuh, Bhuvah, Svah, is called Purusha because of his having the form of a man. I am he.

original: aharamiti copaniṣada uktatvādādityacākṣuṣayostadevedaṃ parāmṛśyate so 'hamasmyamṛtamiti saṃbandhaḥ /
analyzed: aharam iti ca upaniṣadaḥ ukta tvāt āditya cākṣuṣayoḥ tat eva idam parāmṛśyate saḥ ham asmi amṛtam iti saṃbandhaḥ
translated: Because it has been said in the Upanishad Day and Night, the Sun and the Eye are referred to here. The connection is I am that immortal one.

original: mamāmṛtasya satyasya śarīrapāte śarīrastho yaḥ prāṇo vāyuḥ so 'nilaṃ bāhyaṃ vāyumeva pratigacchatu /
analyzed: mama amṛtasya satyasya śarīrapāte śarīra sthaḥ yaḥ prāṇaḥ vāyuḥ saḥ nilam bāhyam vāyum eva pratigacchatu
translated: When the body of mine, which is immortal and true, falls, may the life-breath, which is the air within the body, go to the external air only.

original: tathānyā devatāḥ svāṃ svāṃ prakṛtiṃ gacchantu /
analyzed: tathā anyāḥ devatāḥ svām svām prakṛtim gacchantu
translated: Similarly, may the other deities go to their own original natures.

analyzed: athā idam api bhasma antam sat pṛthivīm yātu śarīram
translated: Then may this body, reduced to ashes, go to the earth.

original: athedānīmātmanaḥ saṃkalpabhūtāṃ manasi vyavasthitāmagnidevatāṃ prārthayateoṃ krato /
analyzed: atha idānīm ātmanaḥ saṃkalpa bhūtām manasi vyavasthitām agni devatām prārthayate om krato
translated: Now he prays to the deity of fire, which has become the resolve of the self and is situated in the mind, with Oṃ, O Kṛta.

analyzed: om iti krato iti ca
translated: The words Oṃ and O Kṛta are used for the purpose of addressing.

analyzed: oṅkāra pratīka tvāt om
translated: It is called Oṃ because it is the symbol of the syllable Oṃ.

analyzed: manaḥ maya tvāt ca kratuḥ
translated: And it is called Kṛta because it is made of the mind.

original: he oṃ he krato smara smartavyamantakāle hi tvatsmaraṇavaśādiṣṭā gatiḥ prāpyate 'taḥ prārthyate yanmayā kṛtaṃ tatsmara punaruktirādarārthā /
analyzed: he om he krato smara smartavyam anta kāle hi tvad smaraṇa vaśāt iṣṭā gatiḥ prāpyate prārthyate yat mayā kṛtam tat smara punar uktiḥ ādara arthā
translated: O Oṃ, O Kṛta, remember the object to be remembered at the time of death, because by the power of remembering you, the desired goal is attained. Therefore, what has been done by me, remember that again. The repetition is for the purpose of respect.

original: kiñca he 'gne naya prāpaya supathā śobhanena mārgeṇa rāye dhanāya karmaphalaprāptaya ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: kiñca he gne naya prāpaya su pathā śobhanena mārgeṇa rāye dhanāya karma phala prāptaye iti arthaḥ
translated: And, O Agni, lead us by the good path to wealth, to prosperity, to the attainment of the fruits of action.

original: na dakṣiṇena kṛṣṇena punarāvṛttiyuktena kiṃ tarhi śuklenaiva supathāsmānviśvāni sarvāṇi he deva vayunāni prajñānāni sarvaprāṇināṃ vidvān /
analyzed: na dakṣiṇena kṛṣṇena punarāvṛtti yuktena kim tarhi śuklena eva su pathā asmān viśvāni sarvāṇi he deva vayunāni prajñānāni sarva prāṇinām vidvān
translated: Not by the southern path which is dark and associated with return, but by the bright path itself, O God, knowing all the ways, all the cognitions of all beings.

original: kiñca yuyodhyapanaya viyojayāsmadasmatto juhurāṇaṃ kuṭilamenaḥ pāpaṃ pāpajātaṃ sarvam /
analyzed: kiñca yuyodhi apanaya viyojaya asmat asmattaḥ juhurāṇam kuṭilam enaḥ pāpam pāpa jātam sarvam
translated: And, O Agni, keep far from us the crooked, the sinful, the evil of every kind that deserves to be avoided.

original: tena pāpena viyuktā vayameṣyāma uttareṇa pathā tvatprasādāt /
analyzed: tena pāpena viyuktāḥ vayam eṣyāmaḥ uttareṇa pathā tvad prasādāt
translated: By that sin we shall go by the northern path, through your grace.

original: kintu vayaṃ tubhyaṃ paricaryāṃ kartuṃ na śaknumo bhūyiṣṭhāṃ bahutamāṃ te tubhyaṃ namauktiṃ namaskāravacanaṃ vidhema namaskāroktyā paricaremetyarthaḥ
analyzed: kintu vayam tubhyam paricaryām kartum na śaknumaḥ bhūyiṣṭhām bahutamām te tubhyam namauktim namaskāra vacanam vidhema namaskāra uktyā paricarema iti arthaḥ
translated: But we are unable to serve you, we offer you the most abundant praise, we pay homage to you by the words of salutation, we serve you by the words of salutation.

original: anyatkartumaśaktāḥ santa iti // //🔽iti śrīmadbṛhadāraṇyakopaniṣadi pañcamādhyāyasya pañcadaśaṃ brāhmaṇam // //
analyzed: anyat kartum aśaktāḥ santaḥ iti  iti śrīmat bṛhat āraṇyaka upaniṣadi pañcama adhyāyasya pañcadaśam brāhmaṇam  /
translated: Being unable to do anything else.🔽Thus ends the fifteenth Brahmana of the fifth chapter in the venerable Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad.

analyzed: iti bṛhat āraṇyaka upaniṣadi pañcamaḥ adhyāyaḥ
translated: Thus ends the fifth chapter in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad.
